oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Computing energy density in one dimension
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Huang, Yichen
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Condensed Matter - Strongly Correlated Electrons
Quantum Physics
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: We study the problem of computing energy density in one-dimensional quantum systems. We show that the ground-state energy per site or per bond can be computed in time (i) independent of the system size and subexponential in the desired precision if the ground state satisfies area laws for the Renyi entanglement entropy (this is the first rigorous formulation of the folklore that area laws imply efficient matrix-product-state algorithms); (ii) independent of the system size and polynomial in the desired precision if the system is gapped. As a by-product, we prove that in the presence of area laws (or even an energy gap) the ground state can be approximated by a positive semidefinite matrix product operator of bond dimension independent of the system size and subpolynomial in the desired precision of local properties.
